text: "I will be making, boeuf bourguignion,"

"Bouef bourguignon."
"Ah."
"Julia Child's bouef bourguignon."
Hey, what's up guys and welcome back to Binging with Babish
where this week, we're making
boeuf bourguignon.
Say it with me,
That's, boeuf bo--
I'm kidding, it's beef burgundy.
It's beef bourguignon, whatever you want to call it.
We're starting with about three pounds of chuck roast
cut into two inch cubes that we're going to season with salt and pepper
before,
chopping up some of everybody's favorite porcine additive.
We're going to cut up some bacon that we're going to,
parboil.
This is going to help render out some of the fat
because we don't want too much fat in our stew.
So we're going to blanch the bacon for two or three minutes
before frying in a large saute pan with a little bit of vegetable oil.
We're going to remove it from the pan once all the fat has rendered out
and it's brown and crispy.
And then we're going to
brown
our, beef in deep bacon fat and oil.
Make sure not to overcrowd your beef
or you're not gonna get that nice
gold crust on every little piece.
Remove the beef from the pan and it's time to add a whole sliced onion
and, four or five peeled and chopped carrots
that we're going to saute in the remaining fat until softened.
Set aside and look what we're left with,
my favorite thing in the world,
fond.
We're going to deglaze this with about,
three cups of crappy, big-jug burgundy
They say that you should only cook with wine that you drink with
but that's not necessarily true when it comes to stews.
Scrape up all that good stuff off the bottom of the pot,
and get a Dutch oven ready.
Place your beef inside and toss with,
maybe a quarter cup of all purpose flour.
This is going to help build up the crust on the beef,
and, eventually thicken our sauce.
Place in a 400 degree oven for about ten minutes or until toasty.
Give them a toss before returning to the oven for another ten minutes
and adding our vegetables and bacon.
Top with the wine from our deglazed pan,
and supplement with beef stock until,
the beef and vegetables are barely covered.
Add three crushed cloves of garlic,
one tablespoon of chopped thyme,
a whole bay leaf,
and a solid two tablespoons of tomato paste that we're going to mix up,
make sure it's well incorporated.
Partially cover with your Dutch oven lid,
reduce the oven temperature to 325 and braise for  three hours, stirring occasionally or until--
Mmm...
While that's in the oven, we're going to make some onions and mushrooms.
We're going to start with about a pound of pearl onions
that we're going to cover with boiling water.
That's is going to make them a lot easier to peel.
Normally, I'd like to just straight up roast these
but we're going to follow Julia's recipe because
Julia knows best
So, once you've got your onions peeled,
it's time to drop them into a hot pan with a little bit of oil.
Toss them around until they're good and brown before deglazing with about
a cup of beef stock.
Cover and braise for about forty-five minutes or until completely soft but retaining their shape.
And lastly, we're going to saute about eight ounces of halved mushrooms in,
two tablespoons of butter.
Once they've expelled most of their moisture,
add about a teaspoon of chopped thyme,
season with salt and pepper
and continue to cook until completely soft about fifteen minutes all told.
At this point, our beef has been braising for about three and a half hours
it's very tender so we're going to pull it out with a pair of thongs,
before straining the liquid,
into a large saucepan.
We're going to aggressively reduce that until it is thick enough to coat the back of the spoon,
like so.
And now I finally get to eat dinner.

couple carrots,
a healthy pile of the strained onions and bacon.

some sauce and freshly chopped parsley.

and,
shocker,
